explanations: For group 1 ます-form verbs, drop ます, change the last syllable from the い-column to the え-column
examples: 3) いそぎます → いそげ
4) あそびます → あそべ

explanations: For group 2 ます-form verbs, drop ます, and add ろ
From ます-form, if します, becomes しろ
From ます-form, if きます, becomes こい
From Verb Jisho form, add な to the end

topic: Uses of the Imperative and Prohibitive forms
explanations: The imperative form is used when demanding that the listener performs a certain action
The prohibitive form is used when demanding that the listener does not perform a certain action
Since they sound strongly coercive, they are rarely used at the end of a sentence, and are used in speech almost exclusively by men
The imperative and prohibitive are used at the ends of sentences in the following types of situations

topic: Imperative and Prohibitive form uses: By a senior in age/status to a junior
explanations: Can also be used by a parent to their child

topic: Imperative and Prohibitive form uses: Among male friends
explanations: The particle よ is often optionally added to the sentence end to soften the tone
examples: 1) 明日[あした] うちへ 来[こ]い(よ)
1) Come to my house tomorrow!(wont you)
2) あまり 飲[の]むな(よ)

topic: Imperative and Prohibitive form uses: When giving instructions in an emergency
explanations: Usually in such cases, they are often only used by men senior in age or status
examples: 2) エレベーターを 使[つか]うな

topic: Imperative and Prohibitive form uses: When giving commands during group training
explanations: Such as school physical education lessons, club sport activities, etc.

topic: Imperative and Prohibitive form uses: When yelling engouragement at a sports events
explanations: Women sometimes also use these form in such cases

topic: Imperative and Prohibitive form uses: On traffic signs and in slogans
explanations: When brevity and impact are required

topic: Imperative form alternative: Verb ます-form なさい
explanations: This is an alternative of the imperative form
It is used by a parent to their child or by a teacher to a pupil, and sounds softer than the imperative form of the verb
Women use this instead of the imperative form of the verb, but it cannot be used when addressing someone of a higher status
examples: 1) 勉[べん]強[きょう]しなさい

topic: ~と 書[か]いて あります/ ~と 読[よ]みます
explanations: [Note] The と particle here is used to report speech indirectly
examples: 1) あの 漢字[かんじ]は 何[なん]と 読[よ]むんですか
1) How do you read that Kanji?
2) あそこに 「止[と]まれ」と 書[か]いて あります

topic: X は Y と いう 意[い]味[み]です
explanations: This form is used when defining X
と いう comes from いいます
When inquiring as to the meaning of somthing, the interrogative どういう is used
examples: 1)「立[たち]入[いり]禁[きん]止[し]」は 入[はい]るなと いう 意[い]味[み]です
2) この マークは どういう 意[い]味[み]ですか
2) ... 洗[せん]濯[たく]機[き]で 洗[あら]えると いう 意[い]味[み]です

topic: ~と 言[い]って いました
forms: Sentence + と 言[い]って いました
V (じしょ-form) + と 言[い]って いました
explanations: ~と いいました is used for quoting what someone said
~と 言[い]って いました is used for reporting what someone said
examples: 1) 田[た]中[なか]さんは 「あした 休[やす]みます」 と 言[い]って いました
1) Mr Tanaka said 'Im taking the day off tomorrow'
2) 田[た]中[なか]さんは あした 休[やす]む と 言[い]って いました
2) Mr Tanaka said he would take the day off tomorrow

topic: ~と 伝[つた]えて いただけませんか
forms: Sentence + と 伝[つた]えて いただけませんか
V (じしょ-form) + と 伝[つた]えて いただけませんか
explanations: This is used when the speaker is polite asking someone to pass a message on for hime or her
examples: 1) ワンさんに 「あとで 電[でん]話[わ]を ください」と 伝[つた]えて いただけませんか
1) Would you mind asking Mr Wang to call me later?
2) すみませんが，渡[わた]辺[なべ]さんに あしたの パーティーを 6時[じ]からだと 伝[つた]えて いただけませんか
2) I'm sorry to bother you, but would you mind telling Ms Watanabe that tomorrows party starts at 6 o'clock?
